_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RB Sandrini has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, RB Sandrini continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved RB Sandrini's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that RB Sandrini's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

RB Sandrini has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, RB Sandrini has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, RB Sandrini now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for RB Sandrini employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program RB Sandrini will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

1.4 Five Year Accident History

RB Sandrini has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

RB Sandrini's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR §1910.38
- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR §68.95
- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731
- California Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
- Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver or directly to the high pressure receiver.

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the ammonia diffusion tanks if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 

Each ammonia refrigeration system at RB Sandrini consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at RB Sandrini are treated as two (2) independent processes. 

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

RB Sandrini has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the RB Sandrini facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Description of Covered Processes

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

The north system control valves are located on the roof to provide easy access. The south system control valves are located alongside the building (elevated). The refrigeration machinery for each system is contained within each machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

Machinery Room (North System)
(2) Screw compressors
(2) Oil separators
(1) Shell and tube oil cooler
(1) Plate and frame oil cooler
(1) High pressure receiver
(1) Liquid transfer vessel
(1) Main suction accumulator
(1) Thermosyphon vessel

Condenser Area
(1) Evaporative condenser
(1) High pressure receiver
(2) Diffusion tanks

Shipping
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

Hallway
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)

Precool North
(1) Accumulator
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 5
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 6
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 7
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 8
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

The systems operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia evaporates to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator. 3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

RB Sandrini operates a commercial cold storage for table grapes in Delano, CA. The facility has two ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

Process 1 - North System
(4) Storage Rooms
(1) Precool Room
(1) Hallway
(1) Shipping Dock

RB Sandrini is located at 11009 Central Valley Hwy, Delano, CA 93215. The latitude and longitude of the System 1 machinery room is 35.755094, -119.343043. The facility is located adjacent to state highway 43 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agricultural land.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is not located in “a special flood hazard area”.
RB Sandrini is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that RB Sandrini has a 1-2% chance of experiencing “potentially minor-damage” due to ground shaking in 2018.

RB Sandrini is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps showed that faults within close proximity are not considered high risk:
Great Valley Thrust Fault System: <150 years
Premier Fault: <150 years
Pond Fault: <150 years
Kern Front Fault: <150 years

With regard to USGS Quaternary Faults, the threat of fault rupture is low. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that RB Sandrini has a 2-5% chance of experiencing “potentially minor-damage” due

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, RB Sandrini has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 RB Sandrini, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that RB Sandrini has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)
North System                  Anhydrous Ammonia                18,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
